PersonC: Sounds good. We'll be having lunch with some French people (the ones who work on the history of food in colonial Mexico - I already see you yawning your head off)
PersonD: YAAAAWN 🙊 Where and where are you meeting?
PersonC: So I'm meeting them at the entrance to the conference hall at 2 pm and then we'll head to this place called La Cantina. Italian cuisine, which is quite funny, but that's what they've chosen

PersonA: Shit, I've got so much to do at work and I'm so demotivated. 
PersonB: It's pretty irresponsible to give that much work to someone on their notice period.
PersonA: Yeah, exactly! Should I even care?
PersonB: It's up to you, but you know what they say...
PersonA: What do you mean?
PersonB: Well, they say how you end things shows how you really are...
PersonA: And now how you start, right?
PersonB: Gotcha! 
PersonA: So what shall I do then? 
PersonB: It's only two weeks left, so grit your teeth and do what you have to do. 
PersonA: Easy to say, hard to perform.
PersonB: Come on, stop thinking, start doing! 
PersonA: That's so typical of you!  ;)

PersonA: Hi, what you up to?
PersonB: Not much, chilling out.
PersonA: Just rewatching Dear White People on Netflix, love it!😍
PersonB: Oh yeah, heard of it, but not seen it yet? Any good?
PersonA: Well, yes! I just said it was, LOL. It's about a fictional Ivy League University and the students in one House of Residence.
PersonB: Why is it called Dear White People?
PersonA: That's the name of the radio show the main character, Sam, presents on college radio.
PersonB: Yeah, but why is it so good?
PersonA: Well, it's mainly stories from the perspective of black students there, which I find very interesting. The characters are strong and likeable too.
PersonB: I suppose it's rather different from the UK, then?
PersonA: It seems so, as there is a lot more racial awareness and discrimination there than here. It all kicks off when there is a Blackface party held by an elite group of white students, which gets out of hand.
PersonB: How's that?
PersonA: Well, obviously, the black students try to break it up and there's also an incident where one guy, Reggie, gets a loaded gun pointed at him by a campus policeman after he gets into an argument with a white student. It may be at another party, though, I'm not sure of that.
PersonB: Oh, that sounds pretty strong stuff. What else happens?
PersonA: Well, there is a young black guy called Lionel who is coming to terms with being gay and is finding his voice as a journalist. He unearths corruption at the uni and he and Sam also uncover some conspiracy theory stuff about secret societies.
PersonB: Well, I must say, it does sound good, I'll check it out soon!
PersonA: Definitely, there is supposed to be a Series 3 coming up next year, really looking forward to it!
PersonB: Well, thanks Clara, I'm just watching the rest of a movie and I'll try Dear White People.
PersonA: Don't blame me if you get hooked and stay up till 4!
PersonB: See ya, love!
PersonA: Bye!

PersonA: How much time do you have for all 4 parts?
PersonB: 4 hours
PersonA: Is it enough?
PersonB: Well it has to be
PersonB: Would be perfect to have 2 more hours... But on the other hand it would be really exhausting
PersonA: 4 hours and no breaks?
PersonB: No breaks :/ So it's really important to be really focused and try to write as fast as you can
PersonB: And read it carefully and correct during the last hour
PersonA: I'm going to read everything from that website, it's great

PersonB: Have you talked to May?
PersonA: Yes, yesterday, why?
PersonB: I just talked to her and I must admit I worry about her
PersonA: Me too, I suggested she should see a specialist, but she wasn't very happy about it
PersonB: No wonder...
PersonA: I know, but I think this is serious. She's saying she's depressed, like everyone around, but in her case it may be true
PersonB: She was telling me she doesn't feel like doing anything, she's bored all the time, she never feels happy. It sounds like a real, typical depression
PersonB: She also told me that she has trouble sleeping. I asked her to go out for a beer or anything basically, but she doesn't want to leave the flat
PersonA: Oh my, it sounds really serious. I don't what to tell you
PersonB: I was wondering how I can help her
PersonA: Honestly I don't know if we can help her, Adam. I suggested a specialist because these are very sensitive issues and I'm afraid we may unintentionally make it worse
PersonB: Yes, but she doesn't want to see a specialist. Basically, she doesn't want to see anyone
PersonA: Hm... I don't know... How about I call someone for advice? So we could know what to do
PersonB: Sounds rational, do you know anyone you could call? Don't mention her name
PersonA: Of course I won't! I have a friend who's a psychologist, we can trust her. I'll let you know
PersonB: Thank you Karen!

PersonB: Okay, Kelly! Ur up nxt!

PersonA: Yeah! What's yours?
PersonC: Fine. It's a sculpture garden in Finnland.
PersonB: What's scary about sculptures? Wait! Do they resemble vampires and stuff?
PersonD: Nah, I'm sure they look rly nice.
PersonC: It's not the sculptures, it's the amount of them and their faces!
PersonA: Faces? What faces?
PersonC: Well, they resemble ppl in different activities like hugging, training, doing sport and so on. But the faces are just morbid and there's like a hundred of them. All staring at you!
PersonB: Another one?
PersonD: Certainly!
PersonA: Well, Ollie, ur turn!
PersonB: Nagoro village in Japan!
PersonD: Y?
PersonB: Well, maybe it's not scary, but it similar to Kelly's place. It's just creepy as hell.
PersonA: Bt y?
PersonB: Imagine a village with ppl living in it. And in the same village u have these human-sized figures. And there's more of them than the ppl that actually live there!
PersonC: Creepy AH!
PersonD: WTF?! Y would ppl even do that?
PersonA: Idk. Idc. Never. Going. There.
PersonB: See! Mine was the worst!
PersonA: Bt not the scariest!
PersonB: Point taken.
PersonD: Listen, guys, fun talking to u, bt gotta go. 
PersonC: Yeah, me too. Bye!
PersonA: Bye!
PersonB: Cu!

PersonB: Hi there! The quince we talked about the other day... Are you still interested?
PersonA: Hello Noah, but of course I am.Thank you.
PersonB: Actually William went to collect the rest of them for you immediately. They're in a basket on our terrace, so you call collect them any time.
PersonA: That's very very kind of him! He's really a darling.
PersonA: We won't be going your direction any time soon I'm afraid. How long will they keep? Is it windfall?
PersonB: Both really but they all look very healthy. No bruises afa one can see. Or only odd small ones. They' be alright for a couple of days I guess. The weather's cool.
PersonA: It would be a shame if they rotted. I'll talk to Frank and maybe to the twins too and go back to you asap.
PersonB: OK.
PersonA: Hey Noah, the twins will be on their way from Notts tomorrow afternoon and passing Windfield. Is it alright if they pop in and collect the quince?
PersonB: Absolutely! In fact anyone can come any time and just take them from our terrace. Of course it would be great to see your twins again. Haven't seen them for ages!
PersonA: Well we don't see that much of them either :( They'll be coming home this weekend only because of Alexa's ceremony.
PersonB: Notts is 3 hours' drive away so small wonder they don't fancy it so much.
PersonA: I don't blame them! We're both happy they've been doing fine at college. Everything's absolutely fine. You don't have William at home all that often either, do you?
PersonB: He gets 5 days at Xmas by way of "family care" and 2 weeks off spread over the whole year but never longer that 5 days. They have a strict regime at the academy. But after all these years we've learned to cope with it. What worries me is that he seems to have no time to even think about getting married and start a family of his own.
PersonA: The fate of most military I guess. Hugely unfair I'd say. Like being married to your regiment!
PersonB: That's what it sounds like when he talks about himself! I never hear a girl's name! And when I ask, he gets brusque.
PersonA: Oh dear! What could it mean?
PersonB: No, not what you think! We know from Capt. Broomsberg about their common escapades. Plenty of women but only that sort of women. No strings.
PersonA: I never even imagined he might be gay! Surely not. But there must be sth else.
PersonB: We think he's just so obsessively career-minded. Nothing else counts for him.
PersonA: He's always been very strong-willed. And he knows what he wants. Well if I were you I wouldn't worry at all.
PersonB: You're probably right. But you know I'd love it so much to have plenty of grandchildren around me.
PersonA: They'll come, don't you worry! Look the twins will contact you about the quince. Alright?
PersonB: Sure. Thank you Sophie for a nice chat!
PersonA: Thank you for the quince!

PersonC: Are you there, Anna?
PersonA: I am, but I am not called Anna. It's Tim.
PersonC: Sorry, brother Tim. Anna is just the word for elder brother in my language.
PersonA: It's a girl's name here. Doesn't sound very brother-like.
PersonC: My apologies. 
PersonA: So what is your language?
PersonC: It is Telugu, brother. 
PersonA: is that spoken in India?
PersonC: Yes, in South east India. Bangalore and Chennai and other places. Nearly 90 million speakers, brother.
PersonA: Is it one of those written right to left?
PersonC: No, it is written left to right. It is based on Brahmin script, our writing. If you trace it back far enough it all comes from the Phoenicians, like English writing the same.
PersonA: Wow. 
PersonA: So it must be pretty big, then, Teluguland?
PersonC: It is 23 provinces, Anna. But we are not rich as in the north, so many people here are still working for less than a hundred dollars a whole month.
PersonA: So what is the word for "younger brother" if "Anna" means "elder brother?"
PersonC: Thammu or Thammadu. You can call me Thammu. I am younger than you.
PersonA: how old are you, I would have sid about the same as me in your photo.
PersonC: How old are you, Anna? 
PersonA: 55
PersonC: Well there you are you see. I am 35 only. So you are my Anna and I am your Thammadu. 
PersonA: Wow sorry to say it but you do look old for PersonB:
PersonC: That is because it is not an easy life when you are not earning much money, Anna. We work very hard and have very little. But still we are thankful for what we do have.

PersonA: Hey, you have a few minutes?

PersonA: I'm thinking about inviting a few people from work over and I kinda thought that maybe some boardgames would be a cool idea.
PersonA: And I wanted to consult the expert on the matter :)
PersonB: As you know I'm always happy to share my expertise with anyone willing to listen. You will just need to stop me when I get too wound up :D
PersonA: Haha :) Ok, So I know you ran the local club - any tips how to organize a newbie gaming evening? And what games to bring?
PersonB: yeah, sure - just a few general tips :)
PersonB: Start games before you start drinking :) And don't bring any game that is either over-complicated, requires too much time to explain, or god forbid encourages direct conflict - you know, the plotting-scheming stuff. So no Game of Thrones :)
PersonB: Or alternatively you can chose some cooperative games - like Arkham Horror, Robinson Crusoe, Pandemic
PersonA: Got it :D 
PersonB: Also would be great to know what theme they all like - if there is one. And if not then there are some 'vanilla' games - like Codenames or Catan. Any idea what they might be into? 
PersonA: Not really - there are some guys who I know like sci-fi and comic books, but no idea about the girls... 
PersonB: The best way - just talk with them - might be surprised by their tastes and experiences. Maybe some of them are already into gaming? There are nerds in every walk of life :)
PersonA: Yeah, I know, all too well :)
PersonA: Anyway, thanks for the tips - co-op games sound like a good idea for a start.
PersonB: yeah, and then if the idea sticks you can roll out the big guns :)

PersonB: Hello. I have had a good look and have done some tests on the mould in your spare bedroom upstairs and in the dinign room.
PersonA: Hello Andy. Thank you for that, what are your thoughts? 
PersonB: I think it is caused by condensation, as most of the moist settles on and around the windows.
PersonA: Why is that?
PersonB: Those are the coldest areas and therefore where the moist in the warm air turns into water. On the windows its just water, on the walls the moist will allow mould to grow.
PersonA: So why is it all over the spare room walls, and all around the dining room? but not in other rooms?
PersonB: Probably because they have external walls which are cooler than internal walls.
PersonA: so why only that bedroom and not the other ones?
PersonB: I guess those rooms are most effected as the spare room is next to the bathroom and the dining room next to the kitchen.
PersonA: But why isnt there mould on the kitchen and bathroom itself then?
PersonB: I think that is because the kitchen doesn't have external walls and the bathroom has only one external wall and a fan in it. The difference when i measured it between internal wall and external wall is about 4 degrees.  
PersonA: Does that mean we need new double glazed windows or new wall insulation?
PersonB: Not necessarily. that would make a little difference but would still leave you with moist air in the house, so it would just settle somewhere else.  
PersonA: So what would you recommend?
PersonB: I would install a fan system, or PIV system, which would circulate air to dilute and take some moisture out of the air. It would be installed in your loft and be on continuously during day and night. 
PersonA: That sounds good. would that be sufficient?

PersonA: U know what annoys me the most?
PersonB: Not being able to watch TV or listen to music without pesky interruptions?
PersonA: That too, but the thing that annoys me the most is pharmaceuticals, medicine and drugs.
PersonB: Y? Aren't they good 4 ur health?
PersonA: They may well be, but not for my wallet!
PersonB: What do u mean?
PersonA: I was watching a film last night and suddenly there's a bunch of commercial of different medical products and so on.
PersonB: And what of it?
PersonA: Imagine that pharmaceutical companies invent illnesses!
PersonB: What? Are u sure?
PersonA: No, I'm not, but in the commercial they mentioned a name of an illness I have never heard of.
PersonB: So what? There are many illnesses and diseases I've never heard of. 
PersonA: So I did some research. Turns out such a thing does not exist. No medical journal writes about it, no medical forum suggests caution.
PersonB: That doesn't mean it doesn't exist. 
PersonA: I even found a youtube video of a doctor explaining y it's not an illness. 
PersonB: All right, this is quite serious.
PersonA: So I put my mind to it and do u know what I came up with?
PersonB: What?
PersonA: That in this particular case they're selling mints as medical products!
PersonB: Srsly?!
PersonA: Absolutely!
PersonB: How long do u think they've been lying to us?
PersonA: Can't be sure, but probably 4ever. Imagine every illness, disease and so on. Where do these come from? Why do they spread so fast?
PersonB: That is kinda puzzling.
PersonA: Right?
PersonB: So why is no one doing anything about it?
PersonA: Do u know how much the pharmaceutical industry is worth today?
PersonB: No.
PersonA: At least $1.2 bln!
PersonB: Explains a lot.
